title: How to Order Food in Korea

steps.headline: Ask the server for recommendations by saying “mow ma-shi-so?” If this is your first time eating Korean cuisine, you might be unsure of what to order.
steps.description: When you have your waiter’s attention, ask “mow ma-shi-so?” which translates to, “what’s delicious?” Your server will recommend popular dishes that you will probably enjoy.

steps.headline: Tell your waiter what you’re allergic to.
steps.description:
If you have any food allergies, make sure you know how to tell your server. Say “so ________ ah-lay-lay-gee say-yo,” and fill in the blank with whatever food you’re allergic to. Some words for common food allergies are listed below:
Peanuts – “tan-kung”
Milk – “woo-you”
Egg – “hi gee-ah-le”
Shellfish – “ju-gay”

steps.headline: Inform the waiter that you’re vegetarian by saying, “sa-lun ches-two-chang-ga.” It’s important that you let the waiter know if you don’t eat meat before ordering your food.
steps.description: They will be able to recommend dishes that or meat free, or make a vegetarian version of a meal that’s not normally vegetarian. If that phrase is too long and hard to pronounce, try saying “ches-two-chang-ga” and point to yourself.

steps.headline: Avoid foods that are too spicy by requesting “an-mep-jeh hey-ju-se-yo.” A lot of Korean food is very spicy.
steps.description: If you’re not comfortable with spicy foods, make sure you let your waiter know before you finish ordering. Say “an-mep-jeh hey-ju-se-yo,” which means, “please don’t make it spicy.”

steps.headline: Order food by pointing to the item you want on the menu and say, “ju say-yo.” If you are unable to read and pronounce Korean characters, you can always point to the foods you want on the menu and show the waiter.
steps.description:
While pointing, say the phrase “ju say-yo,” which means “please give me ____.”
For example, if you want rice you would say, “bab ju say-yo.” That translates to “Please give me rice.”
To ask for an English menu, say “Young-oh may-nu, ee-so-yo.”

steps.headline: Say “kay-san-so  ju-say-yo” to ask for the check.
steps.description:
Korean restaurants typically serve a lot of food. You may not finish everything at your table. When you are finished eating, let the waiter know by saying “kay-san-so  ju-say-yo,” which translates to “please give me the bill.”
Make sure you check your table first. You bill might already be there. If so, bring it to the front of the restaurant to pay.

steps.headline: Sit at any open table that’s available.
steps.description: Most traditional family owned Korean restaurants do not have a host or hostess at the door. So when you walk in, do not wait for someone to seat you. If the dining area is not filled to capacity, you can choose any open table to sit at. Some larger Korean restaurants may have a host that will seat you. When you walk in, check to see if there is a host or hostess near the entrance. If there is, wait for them to seat you at a table.

steps.headline: Grab your own appetizers at self-service restaurants.
steps.description: When you walk in the restaurant, look around and see if you notice an open area with a variety of food. Some Korean eateries are self-serve, similar to salad bars and buffets. Here, you can walk up and get water, kimchi, and other side dishes. At self-service restaurants, you may also have to get up to get your own silverware, napkins, and chopsticks.

steps.headline: Get the waiter’s attention by saying “so-gee-yo.” If you’re already seated at your table and ready to order, call a waiter over by saying “so-gee-yo.” This phrase literally means “over here!” Say it loudly while raising your hand so your server will see you.
steps.description: Some Korean restaurants have a call button you can push to call the waiter. Use that if it is available.

steps.headline: Avoid tipping at most Korean restaurants.
steps.description: Tipping is not required or expected in Korea. In most Korean restaurants, if you try to tip them, they may respectfully decline. Sometimes a 10% tip is already added to the bill! However, if you are at a western style restaurant, they will accept a small tip. A 5-10% tip is enough at a Korean restaurant. Do not just leave your tip on the table. Make sure you give your tip directly to the server. You are not obligated to tip at a bar.

steps.headline: Thank your server by saying “kam-sam ni-da.” Thank your servers before you leave the restaurant.
steps.description: Make sure you smile while saying it. This is seen as a polite gesture and a sign of respect to the people that served and prepared your meal. If you’re really comfortable with you Korean pronunciation, you can say “jal mo-go smi-dah,” which means, “I ate very well.”

steps.headline: Expect to be served banchan at the start of your meal.
steps.description: Banchan are a variety of side dishes that are typically served on small plates before the main course. You typically do not have your waiter ask for these – they’re free! There are hundreds of different kinds of banchan, and the ones you are served will depend on the restaurant you’re visiting. Kimchi is a very popular banchan. It is described as fermented vegetables seasoned with chili peppers and salt. There are different varieties that can be spicy and made with different vegetables (cabbage, scallions, or radishes). Some other examples of banchan are kongnamul (seasoned soybean sprouts), danmuji (pickled radish), and gamja saelleodeu (potato salad. Banchan is usually served with cooked white rice.

steps.headline: Order bibimbap for a delicious rice cuisine.
steps.description: Bibimbap is a very popular Korean dish. It is not too spicy, and consists of a variety of vegetables on top of rice with egg and protein. It is made to be eaten by mixing everything together. This dish is great for vegetarians, because it can be served with tofu and vegetables instead of meat.

steps.headline: Try tteokbokki to experience a spicy dish.
steps.description: Tteokbokki consists of a unique ingredient called eomuk (fish cake), which is a tofu made with fish and other seafood. The dish also consists of hard-boiled eggs, cabbage, onions, green peppers, and scallions. Tteokbokki is a great dish to order if you’re dining with a small group. It is a very heavy dish, so it is recommended that you share it with a group of 3-4 friends.

steps.headline: Eat japchae if you enjoy a sweet and savory taste.
steps.description: Japchae is a stir-fry made with sweet potato starch noodles mixed with spinach, beef, carrots, mushrooms, and onions. It is described as one of Korea’s most loved dishes. Japchae can be overwhelmingly sweet, depending on whom you order from. If you find that it is too sweet, eat it with a savory appetizer, such as kimchi.

steps.headline: Call and tell a restaurant you would like to order for delivery by saying, “bay-dal ee-ay-oh.” If you’d much rather eat at home instead of at a restaurant while you’re in Korea, it’s easy to call and request delivery.
steps.description: You can find a nearby restaurant with a quick Google search. Once you dial the number, the restaurant staff will most likely ask if you are ordering for delivery. Say “bay-dal ee-ay-oh,” which means, “yes, for delivery.”

steps.headline: Have your address ready so the restaurant knows your location.
steps.description: Don’t forget to tell the restaurant where you live. This might be the next thing they ask you over the phone. Start by saying, “ju-sue-nen…,” which means, “the address is…” then state your address. You usually do not need to include the city when you are saying your address. Korean restaurants will only deliver locally. Start off by telling them the neighborhood you are staying in.

steps.headline: Let the restaurant know if you will be paying by card (“ka-due”) or cash (“chang-gume”).
steps.description: The restaurant will need to know how you will be paying the delivery driver. Say, “ka-due-lo kal-che gay-oh” if you’re paying with a card, or say “chang-gum kal-che gay-oh” to tell them you’ll pay with cash.

steps.headline: Use a Korean food delivery app.
steps.description: You may be familiar with food delivery services and apps in the United States. Luckily, if you’re in Korea and you need some food delivered to your location, you can use a food delivery app to do so. One app, called Shuttle, is available in Seoul, and is completely in English! You can order a variety of foods, including pizza, Chinese, and of course, traditional Korean. Some other popular delivery apps are Yogiyo and Uber Eats. Yogiyo is completely in Korean, so you’ll need some knowledge of Hangul (the Korean alphabet) to use the app.
